Helen Gibson

Helen Gibson

First female stunt woman

Here's a timeline of Helen Gibson's life:

  • 1892 - Born as Rose August Wegner in Cleveland, Ohio
  • 1909 - Saw her first Wild West Show
  • 1909 - Answered a "girl riders wanted" Ad in Billboard Magazine
  • 1910 - Performed in her first 101 Ranch Real Wild West Show in St. Louis
  • 1913 - Helen featured in the Standing Woman Race, impressing one of the investors that he offered to finance a tour of rodeos for her, paying all expenses and splitting the winnings.
  • 1913 - Helen met Edmund Richard "Hoot" Gibson in Pendleton. They began working together, won many rodeos and began to successfully tour. They "tied the knot" purely for convenience to gain priority access to room rentals.
  • 1915 - Helen performed what is thought to be her most dangerous stunt: a leap from the roof of a station onto the top of a moving train.
  • 1915-1917 - Helen proved to be a capable actress in her own right when she had the opportunity to replace the actress she stunt doubled for. Gibson performed in "The Hazards of Helen" for 69 episodes.
  • 1917-1920 - Helen continued to be offered contracts but many of the production companys were in decline and going out of business.
  • 1920 - Helen created Helen Gibson Productions only for her to face bankruptcy herself.
    - Hoot Gibson's ego could not handle that his wife had become a very successful movie star, the couple separated.
  • 1921 - After her recovery from surgery, Gibson's popularity as a lead had waned. An additional spell in hospital forced her to sell her furniture, jewellery, and car
  • 1924 - Gibson resulted to trick riding for the next two and a half years.
  • 1927 - Helen returned to Hollywood and began doubling for numerous stars. She worked constantly stunt doubling and in uncredited or bit parts.
  • 1935 - Helen married Clifton Johnson, a studio electrician.
  • 1940 - Helen became treasurer of the stunt girl's fraternal organization.
  • 1951 - Helen was cast as a retired silent film actress.
  • 1954 - Helen continued to take character parts and extra work, but it was in this year that the couple moved to Lake Tahoe for health reasons.
  • 1957 - Helen suffered a stroke but it did not prevent her working as an extra in film and television.
  • 1961 - Helen performed in her last role at the age of 69.
  • 1962 - Helen retired.
  • 1977 - Helen Gibson died of heart failure following a stroke, aged 85.

If you'd like to find out more about this bold woman you should visit her Wikipedia Page
